Fig. 1 (a) Schematic illustration of the synthetic processes for the two SBA-CPE materials investigated in this work, denoted CPE-1 and CPE-2. (b–e) The SEM images of SPE, GPE, CPE-1, and CPE-2. (f) Rate capability performances of CPE-1, CPE-2, and GPE at room temperature (1 C = 170 mAh g−1). (g) PVDF polymorphism showing the α and β-PVDF crystalline phases. (h) XRD patterns revealing the phase changes in PVDF, PVDF-DMF, SPE, GPE, and CPE, with the dashed vertical lines distinguishing the α and β-phase transition. Fig. 2 Electrochemical characterization and performance for CPE-1. (a) Ionic conductivity and activation energy obtained between 25 and 70 °C via EIS methods. (b) Li-ion self-diffusion coefficients measured from 25 to 70 °C using 7Li PFG-NMR at 14.1 T. (c) Current-time profile at room temperature (inset showing the EIS plot before and after polarization), showing Li-transference number (t Li+) of 0.42. (d) LSV of Li|CPE-1|SS and Li|GPE|SS cells analyzed over the potential range of 3.0–5.5 V vs. Li/Li+ at room temperature, revealing a high voltage stability for CPE-1, i.e., ca. 4.8 V. (e) Galvanostatic charge–discharge profile for LFP|CPE-1|Li cell at different C-rates and room temperature (1 C = 170 mAh g−1). (f) Cycle performance of the assembled LFP|CPE-1|Li cell (discharging current density = 0.2 C at 25 °C, 1 C = 170 mAh g−1), showing >90 % capacity retention after 150 cycles. (g) Rate performance for CPE-1 with and without plasticizer at 50 and 60 °C. Fig. 3 1H NMR spectra unraveling the structures of (a) PVDF-based CPEs assisted by tracking the structural changes stepwise from PVDF-DMF, SPE, and GPE with increased complexity of the system, and the controlled systems of (b) PVDF-solvent (DMF) and (c) PVDF-plasticizer (PC/EC). Peak assignments for CPE-1 and CPE-2 materials (especially the mobile and rigid PVDF signals) are elaborated in the related contexts. All samples in (a) were vacuumed at 60 °C for 6 h. All solid NMR spectra, i.e., i–vi in (a) and all spectra in (c), were acquired at 18.8 T, MAS = 15 kHz; liquid NMR spectra in (b) were acquired at 9.4 T. Fig. 4 (a) 1H-13C correlation for the SPE sample obtained via CP HETCOR, showing the correlation of 2.7 ppm proton to the carbons in PVDF and DMF. (b) The CPE-1 proton spectrum acquired at varying temperatures as indicated, showing the mobile PVDF chemical shift dependence on temperature (from 3.65 to 3.97 ppm). Note that there is a universal change of chemical shift (spectral drift) due to the temperature change, ∼0.05 ppm from 16 to −40 °C, but far smaller than that for the mobile PVDF signal. Fig. 5 (a) 1H-1H NOESY NMR spectrum acquired for CPE-1, showing the correlations among rigid/mobile polymer segments in PVDF and their interactions with PC/EC and DMF. The main correlations between the rigid/mobile PVDF, DMF, PC/EC, and the diamond-marked components are denoted and distinguished by color, with detailed description/discussion presented in the related contexts. (b, c) The 1H MAS NMR spectra of CPE-1 and CPE-2 vacuum dried at different temperatures as indicated in each figure, to track the removal of solvent and plasticizer. All spectra were acquired at 18.8 T, with MAS = 15 kHz. Fig. 6 Investigation of Li+ mobility in electrolyte materials CPE-1 and CPE-2. (a) 2D 1H-7Li correlation spectra acquired by HOESY (left) and CP HETCOR (right) for CPE-1, with the proton spectrum aligned along the F1 direction for peak identification. Notably, the mobile PVDF signal shows weak correlation in the CP HETCOR spectrum but yields a strong correlation to Li+ in the HOESY spectrum. (b) 2D 1H-7Li HOESY spectrum and the corresponding proton spectrum for CPE-2, showing the most intense correlation formed by the mobile PVDF species (3.8 ppm proton peak). All spectra were acquired at 9.4 T, with MAS = 10 kHz. Fig. 7 Schematic diagram of the Li+ transport pathways for CPE-1, highlighting the contribution from rigid/mobile PVDF polymer regions and solvent-Li+ complexes. ☆ This article is part of a special issue entitled: ‘Nova of Energy Chemistry’ published in Journal of Energy Chemistry. Graphical abstract Solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (ssNMR) reveals Li+ transport pathways contributed by mobile and rigid polymer segments, as well as solvent-Li+ complexes, in PVDF-based composite polymer electrolytes. Composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs) are considered as promising electrolytes for next-generation lithium batteries due to their superior advantages in safety, mechanical stability/flexibility, cathode compatibility, etc. However, achieving high Li+ conductivity remains a major challenge, particularly at low temperatures. A key obstacle lies in the limited understanding of the complex interplay among amorphous components, including fillers, plasticizers, and residual solvents, which significantly hampers the rational design of high-performing CPEs. In this contribution, a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF)-based composite electrolyte has been developed, exhibiting high room-temperature ionic conductivity/mobility (>1 mS cm−1/0.95 × 10−11 m2 s−1), along with excellent electrochemical performances, including a wide stability window (4.8 V vs. Li/Li+), superior charge/discharge capacity, and reversibility. By performing advanced solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (ssNMR) techniques, in combination with systematic investigations into solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs), gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs), and CPEs, we establish an efficient NMR-based strategy for deconvoluting the structural and dynamic features of complex electrolyte systems. Notably, the simple 1H magic-angle spinning (MAS) NMR spectroscopy enables the identification and monitoring of nearly all components in the composite matrix. Motion-sensitive 1H-13C and 1H-7Li correlation experiments further reveal that the rigidity of PVDF polymer chain segments and the presence of residual solvents are two critical factors governing Li+ mobility. Moreover, we demonstrate that the order of the filler and plasticizer addition during the CPE fabrication significantly influences the performance of the electrolyte by regulating the retention of residual solvents. This work not only provides molecular-level insights into the structure-ion mobility relationships in the PVDF-based CPEs but also establishes a general NMR-based characterization approach for investigating other complex composite electrolyte materials. Keywords Solid-state battery PVDF-based electrolyte Solid-state NMR Lithium-ion transport Ionic conductivity 1 Introduction Despite the rapid growth of lithium-ion batteries (LIBs) in energy storage-related fields, such as portable devices, electric vehicles, and grid-scale storage, safe and durable electrolytes are still highly demanded [1,2]. To date, most commercial LIBs employ liquid electrolytes that usually contain large amounts of organic solvents, raising general safety concerns, including leakage, flammability, thermal runaway, and short circuit [3,4]. Such issues can be significantly mitigated by using solid-state electrolytes (SEs) that provide both promising Li+ conductivity and high mechanical strength and thermal stability. Polymer electrolytes (PEs) are a promising type of SE candidate, provided their general advances in, for example, low-cost, low-density, high-flexibility, and highly tunable structure [5–7]. Yet, their widespread application is still hindered by low ionic conductivities at ambient temperatures, necessitating a deeper understanding of the Li+ transport pathways in the structurally complex polymer matrices. In general, PEs can be conveniently divided into three categories: (1) solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs) prepared by dissolving Li salts into polymer matrix, (2) gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs, quasi-liquid) prepared with involvement of solvents and plasticizers to improve ionic conductivity, and (3) composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs) which incorporate ceramic or inorganic fillers such as lithium lanthanum titanate (LLTO), lithium lanthanum zirconium oxide (LLZO), or SiO2 to enhance the mechanical strength while maintaining ionic conductivity [8,9]. Among them, CPEs offer a promising balance of ionic conductivity, stability, processability, safety, and tunability. However, consisting of the polymer matrix, residual solvent, dissolved Li salt, plasticizer, and filler particles, the complex and inhomogeneous microstructure of the material makes it extremely challenging to investigate the Li+ transfer pathways, thus hindering further performance optimization [10,11]. Solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (ssNMR) spectroscopy has emerged as a powerful tool for elucidating the invaluable structural and dynamic information in such complex systems, owing to its characteristics of atomic-level resolution, non-invasive detection, and high sensitivity to local microstructures [12,13]. It allows for probing the detailed local structure, crystalline/amorphous phase differentiation, and the much-needed behavior of Li+ mobility in CPEs, and is particularly suited for disordered and amorphous materials [12–14]. To date, most NMR studies have focused on relatively simple systems, such as poly(ethylene oxide) (PEO)-based SPE or CPE materials, due to the straightforward repeating –CH2CH2O– units and the relatively high polymer stability [13,15,16]. In contrast, in-depth NMR investigations on more complicated polymer bases, such as polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) or polyvinylidene fluoride-co-hexafluoropropylene (PVDF-HFP), remain limited. In these CPEs, polymer matrices render more complex functional groups and diverse Li+ coordination sites, and can also undergo internal structural change during processing. These complexities, together with the interaction from filler, plasticizer, residual solvent, etc., significantly increase the difficulty of characterization [17]. Recently, various studies have shown that solvents can hardly be removed completely from the system, and may even assist Li+ conductivity by forming a solvent-Li+ complex [17–19]. However, efficient characterization methods are still lacking in investigating these complexes. Here, a PVDF-based CPE material fabricated with appropriately selected additives, i.e., N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF) as solvent, a mesoporous silica material (SBA-15) as filler, propylene carbonate/ethylene carbonate (PC/EC) as plasticizer, and LiTFSI as Li salt, demonstrates excellent electrochemical performance: high room-temperature ionic conductivity (>1 mS cm−1), a wide stability window (4.8 V vs. Li/Li+), a discharge capacity of 154 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C (for LiFePO4 cathode), high charge/discharge reversibility with 90 % retention over 160 cycles at 0.2 C, and a large Li+ transference number (0.42). To uncover the underlying mechanisms behind these remarkable properties, advanced NMR techniques, including the high-field NMR (up to 18.8 T) and motion-sensitive two-dimensional (2D) correlation methods, were employed to systematically explore the microstructural and dynamic features of PVDF-based SPE, GPE, and CPE systems. It is shown that: (a) the electrochemical performance is primarily governed by the balance between rigid and mobile segments within the PVDF polymer chains, (b) the residual solvent content significantly enhances the Li+ conductivity through the formation of Li+-solvent complexes, and (c) the order of additive incorporation (the filler and plasticizer) during synthesis critically impacts the residual solvent content and thereby the overall performance. These findings not only offer unprecedented molecular-level insights into the structural complexity and ion transport mechanism of PVDF-based CPEs but also establish new approaches for investigating Li+/polymer mobility in advanced composite electrolyte systems. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials All chemicals were purchased and used without any further purification. Natural abundance DMF (99.8 %) and DMF-d7 (99.5 %), acetone (97 %), and N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP, 99.9 %) were purchased from Aladdin. PVDF and Super P were purchased from Canrd. PC, EC, and lithium bis(trifluoromethanesulfonyl)imide (LiTFSI) were purchased from DodoChem. LiFePO4 (LFP, 98 %) was obtained from Macklin. Carbon-coated aluminum foil substrate (size: 260 mm W × 16 μm T, coating width: 220 mm, coating thickness: 1 μm per side) was purchased from MTI Corporation. SBA-15 (6–11 nm in pore size, specific surface area: 550–600 m2 g−1) was purchased from XFNANO. Lithium metal anodes (500 µm, 15 mm) were purchased from China Energy Lithium Co., Ltd. Sensitive chemicals like LiTFSI were stored in an argon-filled glove box (H2O < 0.01 ppm, O2 < 0.01 ppm). 2.2 Sample preparation 2.2.1 Preparation of SPE and GPE membranes The samples were prepared using a solution-casting method. First, PVDF was dried at 60 °C for 24 h to remove absorbed water. SPE was prepared by dissolving PVDF and LiTFSI with a weight ratio (1:1) in DMF, followed by mechanical stirring to achieve a homogeneous slurry. The homogenized viscous mixture was cast onto a Teflon plate (80 mm diameter) and aged at room temperature for 3 h. The solvent was slowly evaporated at 60 °C for 12 h, followed by vacuum drying at 60 °C for 6 h. The resulting SPE film had an average thickness of approximately 175 μm. The film was punched into 19 mm-diameter discs and stored in a glove box (O2, H2O < 0.01 ppm). GPE samples were prepared similarly, with the addition of 0.6 mL plasticizer (PC/EC) to the casting solution before film formation. 2.2.2 Preparation of PVDF-based CPE membranes The PVDF-based CPEs were prepared by adding fillers into GPE. A series of materials, i.e., Al2O3, SiO2, MCM-41, SBA-15, MOR, and 4A, were tested with respect to electrolyte performance, and SBA-15 was chosen as the optimal type throughout the work (Fig. S1a). Two CPE materials, namely, CPE-1 and CPE-2, were prepared following a similar method, only with a reversed order of the filler and plasticizer addition. In detail, CPE-1 was synthesized by dissolving 0.25 g PVDF and LiTFSI into 3 mL DMF. This was followed by adding 0.6 mL plasticizer (PC/EC) and 25 mg SBA-15 filler. The mixture was magnetically stirred until a homogenous viscous mixture was obtained. For CPE-2, PVDF and the SBA-15 filler were first dissolved in DMF, followed by the addition of LiTFSI and plasticizer. Both CPE-1 and CPE-2 mixtures were cast onto a Teflon plate (80 mm diameter), aged at room temperature for 3 h, dried at 60 °C for 12 h, and vacuum-dried for 6 h. The resulting films were approximately 175 μm thick. 2.2.3 Preparation of PVDF-solvent films PVDF was dissolved in individual solvents (DMF, PC, EC, and PC-EC). The samples were stirred, cast onto Teflon plates, and dried at 60 °C in an oven for 12 h, followed by vacuum drying for 6 h. 2.2.4 Preparation of LFP electrode The LFP cathode was prepared by mixing 80 % LiFePO4 (LFP), 10 % Super P, and 10 % PVDF (dissolved in NMP) into a slurry. The mixture was cast onto the carbon-coated aluminum foil (size: 260 mm W × 16 μm T, coating width: 220 mm, coating thickness: 1 μm per side, purchased from MTI Corporation) and vacuum dried at 100 °C for 12 h. The electrode was then punched into 14 mm-diameter discs and vacuum-dried at 100 °C for 1 h before being transferred to a glove box for battery assembly. The LFP active mass loading was ca. 2.976 mg cm−2, weighed inside the glovebox to minimize impacts from moisture. 2.3 Electrochemical measurement All cells were assembled into the CR2032 coin-type in an argon-filled glove box (O2, H2O < 0.01 ppm) for electrochemical performance testing. Electrochemical characterizations were conducted using a CHI660 electrochemical workstation. Ionic conductivities were determined by the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) method at a frequency range (from 50 mHz to 1 MHz) with an applied amplitude of 10 mV. The ionic conductivities were determined using Eq. (1) (1) σ = L R b × S where σ is the ionic conductivity, L is the film thickness (cm), R b is the bulk resistance, and S is the cross-sectional area. The thickness of the film was determined by a micrometer. Films were sandwiched between stainless steel (SS|PE|SS) for EIS measurements and tested between 25 and 70 °C. The activation energy (E a) of the CPE-1 was calculated by fitting the Vogel-Tammann-Fulcher (VTF) (Eq. (2)) (2) σ = A T 1 2 e x p - E a R ( T - T 0 ) where A represents the pre-exponential factor, T is the temperature (K), R is the universal gas constant (0.008314 kJ K−1 mol−1), and T 0 is the reference temperature, considered between 10 and 50 K below the glass transition temperature of the polymer electrolyte (T g -50 K) [11,20]. T g of PVDF is −35 °C [14]. The activation energy of CPE-1 based on Li+ self-diffusion coefficient between 25 and 70 °C was calculated by fitting the Arrhenius equation (Eq. (3)) [21] (3) D = D o e x p - E a RT where D is the diffusion coefficient (m2 s−1), E a represents the activation energy (J mol−1), R is the molar gas constant (8.314 J K−1 mol−1), and T is the absolute temperature (K). The electrochemical stability window of PEs was examined by linear sweep voltammetry (LSV) on an asymmetrical SS|PE|Li coin cell with a sweep rate of 5 mV s−1 over 3.0–5.5 V (vs. Li/Li+). Lithium transference number (t Li+) was determined by alternating current (AC) impedance and direct current (DC) polarization on a symmetric Li|PE|Li cell. A 5 mV DC polarization was applied to measure the initial and steady-state currents, with EIS spectra recorded before and after polarization (500 mV amplitude, from 50 mHz to 1 MHz). The t Li+ was calculated using the Bruce-Vincent approach in Eq. (4) (4) t L i = I s ( Δ V - I 0 R 0 ) I 0 ( Δ V - I s R s ) where I 0 and I s represent the initial and steady-state currents, respectively. R 0 and R s denote the interface resistances at the beginning and after polarization. Δ V is the polarization voltage in mV. The interfacial compatibility between the CPE-1 and Li metal was examined using Li plating/stripping cycling in a symmetric Li|PE|Li coin cell. The current density was set at 0.1 mA cm−2. Galvanostatic charge/discharge tests were performed on a Land CT3002A system between 25 and 60 °C, with LFP/PE/Li cell voltages ranging from 3.0 to 4.1 V. 2.4 Materials characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was conducted at room temperature using a Rigaku D/MAX-2500 diffractometer with Cu K α radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å) over a 2θ range of 10°–55°, at a scan rate of 10° min−1. The surface morphology of PEs was investigated using scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Quanta 200F). The samples were mounted on a double-sided carbon adhesive tape attached to a sample holder, sputtered with platinum to improve conductivity and imaging quality, and acquired under vacuum as part of routine SEM characterization. 2.5 NMR analysis Solid-state NMR (ssNMR) experiments were recorded on a variety of instruments at 9.4, 14.1, 18.8 T (1H Larmor frequencies at 400, 600, and 800 MHz), with Bruker Avance III (14.1 T) or NEO (9.4 and 18.8 T) consoles. The 800 MHz spectrometer was fitted with a 3.2 mm HX DVT probe, while the 400 MHz spectrometer was equipped with a 4 mm H/F-X double resonance MAS (magic-angle spinning) NMR probe. The samples were packed in standard 3.2 and 4 mm Zirconia (ZrO2) rotors sealed with Vespel® caps. NMR spectra were referenced to adamantane for 1H chemical shift at 1.74 ppm and 1 M LiCl for 7Li chemical shift at 0 ppm. The DMFIT software was used to deconvolute the 7Li MAS NMR spectrum. Detailed ssNMR experimental parameters are provided in Table S1. Liquid-state NMR (lsNMR) experiments were conducted on a 9.4 T (400 MHz 1H Larmor frequency) Bruker AVANCE III spectrometer. The 1H NMR spectra were recorded using a flip angle of 30°, an acquisition time of 2 s, and a pulse delay of 5 s. The scan number ranged from 16 to 512. 7Li Pulsed-field gradient (PFG) NMR experiments were performed on a Bruker Avance III 14.1 T spectrometer equipped with a 5 mm Bruker Diff50 probe for self-diffusion measurements at temperatures between 25 and 70 °C. The diffusion coefficient was obtained by fitting the gradient-dependent echo intensity to Eq. (5) [22] (5) I = I 0 e - D [ ( 2 π γ g δ ) 2 ( Δ - δ 3 ) ] where γ is the 7Li gyromagnetic ratio, g is the strength of the field gradient along the z direction (G m−1), D is the diffusion coefficient, I and I 0 are the echo intensities with and without the gradient field, δ is the pulse width of the field gradient pulses, and Δ is the duration time between the two pulses (diffusion time). The parameters of PFG experiments are presented in Table S1. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fabrication of high-performance PVDF-based CPEs In CPE membranes, the morphology, dynamics, and stability that govern the electrochemical performance are influenced by the physical and chemical interactions among the polymer matrix, solvent, plasticizer, and filler. However, the complexity of the composite components makes it challenging to isolate the contributions from one another. In the PVDF-based system chosen in this work, DMF and a PC/EC mixture were used as solvent and plasticizer, respectively, given their excellent compatibility with PVDF polymers [23,24]. The choice of filler was determined to be SBA-15, a porous silica material, based on in-house performance tests among particle Al2O3, particle SiO2, porous silica (MCM-41 and SBA-15), and a few zeolite materials (MOR and 4A), as shown in Fig. S1(a). With this optimized selection of components, a series of PVDF-based SPE, GPE, and CPE membranes were prepared, as illustrated in Fig. 1 , with detailed fabrication procedures outlined in Section 2. The two PVDF-based CPEs differ only in the order of filler and Li salt addition, denoted CPE-1 and CPE-2, respectively. In general, a highly developed porous structural system is essential for promoting ionic conductivity, mechanical flexibility, membrane wettability, etc. [25]. Fig. 1(b–e) depicts the SEM images of the fabricated membranes of SPE, GPE, and the two CPE materials, which were vacuum-dried at 60 °C to remove solvents. Evidently, both CPE-1 and CPE-2 exhibit significantly enhanced porous textures compared to SPE and GPE. SPE comprises dense and compact microstructures, likely due to crystallization and solvent evaporation [26], while GPE shows a more uniform structure with limited porosity likely arising from phase separation or accumulation of plasticizer (EC/PC) within the voids [27]. The rate-dependent electrochemical cycling performances of these PVDF-based electrolytes were evaluated at room temperature, as presented in Fig. 1(f). SPE is excluded from this plot due to its very low ionic conductivity, while its performance at 50 °C is depicted in Fig. S1b), yet it is still outperformed by the room-temperature CPE-1. Of the LFP cathode prepared following the preparation procedure described in Section 2.2.4, GPE exhibits a rapid capacity decay from 161 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C to 58 mAh g−1 at 1 C, corresponding to a 64.0 % capacity loss that could be attributed to severe polarization [28,29] and passive film formation near the cathode interface [1], both of which hinder ion transport and decrease electrochemical kinetics. In contrast, CPE-1 delivers a similar capacity of 154 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C, but with a minimal decay to 114 mAh g−1 at 1 C, achieving a 74.0 % capacity retention, significantly outperforming both GPE and SPE. CPE-2 shows relatively lower performance than CPE-1, with reduced capacity ranging from 131 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C to 98 mAh g−1 at 1 C, highlighting the critical role of the order of introducing additives during the synthesis process. To understand the PVDF behavior in the CPE materials, it is first worth discussing possible crystalline phase transition during the fabrication process, as it significantly influences the pyro- and piezoelectric properties that are related to the coordination capability of Li+ ions [30,31]. In general, there are five crystalline phases (α, β, γ, δ, and ε) for PVDF, where the α- and β-phases illustrated in Fig. 1(g) are common conformations for PVDF, with the former exhibiting trans-gauche (TGTG) and the latter exhibiting all trans-configuration (TTTT) [32]. XRD patterns (Fig. 1h) clearly show that the pristine PVDF exhibits α-phase features, while DMF-treated PVDF and all PEs exhibit predominant β-phases. Indeed, it has been reported that for film castings, solvent-evaporating temperature above 70 °C favors the formation of α-phase, whereas temperature below 70 °C favors β-phase [32], and DMF is an effective solvent to dissolve and transform PVDF from α-phase to β‐phase [31]. Also, our experimental data show that neither PC/EC nor acetone can induce an α-to-β phase transition (Fig. S2), which corroborates the unique feature of DMF. Therefore, the α-to-β phase transition upon fabricating the CPE materials is in accordance with the membrane casting conditions, i.e., the use of DMF solvent and vacuum drying at 60 °C (<70 °C). Fortunately, the β-phase PVDF exhibits apparently higher polarity, making it more desirable for electrolyte applications compared to the α phase, which could partly account for the excellent performance of the CPE materials. In all, considering the superior performance of CPE-1 and CPE-2 over SPE and GPE, and that the distinct differences between the two CPEs arising solely from the filler addition sequence, the following sections will focus on a comprehensive investigation of the structure–property relationship among these electrolytes, especially the factors that govern Li+ transport using advanced solid-state NMR techniques. 3.2 Electrochemical properties and performances of PVDF-CPE The electrochemical properties of the best-performing material, CPE-1, were further investigated for potential battery applications, as shown in Fig. 2 . Li+ mobility was first evaluated using EIS and PFG-NMR techniques, in the temperature range of 25–70 °C, as illustrated in Fig. 2(a, b). Specifically, the ionic conductivities (determined via AC impedance measurements, Fig. S3a) were found to be 1.21, 1.38, 1.77, 2.13, 2.44, and 2.9 mS cm−1, while self-diffusion coefficients (from 7Li PFG-NMR, as detailed in the Experimental section) were 0.95, 0.98, 1.41, 2.16, 2.7, and 3.43 (10−11 m2 s−1) at 25, 30, 40, 50, 60, and 70 °C, respectively. Notably, the room-temperature ionic conductivity of 1.21 mS cm−1 and self-diffusion coefficient of 0.95 10−11 m2 s−1 are among the highest reported for solid-state electrolytes (see Tables S2 and S3). Further fitting the variable-temperature EIS and PFG results yields activation energies of Li+ transport as 1.376 kJ mol−1 (Fig. S3b) and 24.18 kJ mol−1 (Fig. S3b) using the VTF equation (Eq. (2)) [33] and Arrhenius equation (Eq. (3)) [21], respectively. Such a great discrepancy is likely due to the presence and absence of the electric field and the influence of ion pairs or clusters, i.e., EIS probes the motion of light Li+ ions, whereas PFG probes heavier ion pairs [34,35]. Subsequently, the electrode compatibility and electrochemical stability for CPE-1 were evaluated. Its charge transfer resistance (R ct), measured as 20.72 Ω, is significantly lower than that of GPE (43.28 Ω), as shown in Fig. S4(a), indicating improved electrolyte-electrode interfacial compatibility. This improvement is likely due to the suppression of plasticizer decomposition, which is known to cause ring-opening polymerization and form resistive interphases near the cathode in GPE systems [1]. Additionally, CPE-1 exhibits a high charge transference number (t Li+) of 0.42, determined via the Bruce-Vincent method (Fig. 2c), indicating enhanced Li+ transport capability, which is critical for suppressing lithium dendrite growth [36]. Supporting this, a symmetric Li|CPE-1|Li coin cell demonstrated stable cycling over 1100 h at 0.1 mA cm−2 and 1 C, with a minimal overpotential (0.025 V), confirming its excellent resistance to lithium dendrite formation (Fig. S4b). LSV analysis determined the electrochemical stability window of CPE-1 to be 4.8 V (Fig. 2d), which is wider than that of GPE (4.6 V). The smooth anodic response further indicates the absence of oxidizable impurities, supporting its compatibility with high-voltage cathodes such as LFP. The galvanostatic charge-discharge profile of CPE-1 at different C-rates (Fig. 2e) revealed small voltage polarization (e.g., 46 mV at 0.1 C), which is likely due to high ionic conductivity and effective electrolyte infiltration into the cathode [28,37]. The cycling performance of the Li|CPE-1|LFP coin cell at room temperature displayed an initial discharge capacity of 149 mAh g−1 with a 90 % capacity retention after 160 cycles at 0.2 C (Fig. 2f). The remarkable cycling performance suggests the potential of CPE-1 for practical applications in high-performance solid electrolytes. The temperature effects on the cycling performance were further examined at 50 and 60 °C, respectively, as shown in Fig. 2(g). While the SPE material exhibits poor performance at room temperature and requires elevated temperatures for effective ionic transport and efficient performance (Fig. S1b), CPE-1 maintains excellent performance across all temperatures tested. Its comparable performance at room temperature (Fig. 1f) and elevated temperatures (Fig. 2g) stands out in contrast to the temperature-sensitive SPE behavior, suggesting that CPE-1 possesses an intrinsically enhanced Li+ transport and improved electrode-electrolyte interfacial contact even at ambient temperature. Interestingly, at 50 °C, the performance remained nearly unchanged with or without the plasticizer, indicating that crystalline PVDF may not significantly influence Li+ mobility. Such a phenomenon likely points to either the involvement of large amounts of amorphous PVDF phases or an alternative Li+ transport mechanism, such as solvent-Li+ complexation, as previously proposed [30]. A detailed understanding of this mechanism requires further investigation into the structure, dynamics, and interplay of individual components within the CPE system, as discussed below. 3.3 Structural elucidation of the PVDF-CPE materials To unravel the factors that contribute to the enhanced performance of the CPE materials, it is essential to understand the interactions among various components, as well as their coordination with Li+. Despite the complexity of the materials, valuable insights can be gained by analyzing the 1H MAS NMR spectra, as shown in Fig. 3 . The 1H NMR spectra of pristine PVDF, DMF-PVDF (dissolved and vacuum dried), SPE, GPE, and the two CPE samples are presented in Fig. 3(a), labeled as spectra i–vi, respectively, and all samples were vacuumed dried at 60 °C for 6 h to ensure consistent solvent removal. The liquid PC/EC proton spectrum is included as a chemical shift reference. Due to the overlapping and complexity of the resonances in spectra iii–vi, direct interpretation is challenging. Hence, to assist the spectral assignment, 1H NMR spectra of DMF and its mixtures with PVDF and/or PC/EC were obtained as controls (Fig. 3b, c). Fig. 3(b) highlights the characteristic DMF signals at 7.8, 2.8, and 2.7 ppm, corresponding to the “f”, “h”, and “g” protons, respectively, as denoted in the DMF structure in Fig. 3(a). Fig. 3(c) and the bottom spectrum in Fig. 3(a) together present the characteristic signals of the PC/EC mixture (labeled “a–e”), along with the spectral changes upon mixing with PVDF. For the pristine PVDF sample (spectrum i), a broad signal centered at 2.5 ppm corresponds to the –CH2– groups, broadened by strong 1H-1H homonuclear dipolar coupling. For the DMF-treated PVDF (spectrum ii), the peak slightly shifts to 2.7 ppm, which is likely associated with an α → β phase transition induced by DMF treatment [32], consistent with the XRD pattern in Fig. 1(h). With respect to the SPE, GPE, and both the CPE spectra, i.e., spectra iii–vi in Fig. 3(a), two distinct resonances at ∼3.7–3.8 and 2.7 ppm are observed across all the samples. These signals can be unambiguously assigned to PVDF for a few reasons. First, by comparing the chemical shift of PVDF signals in SPE (spectrum iii, essentially “PVDF+DMF”), the 3.7–3.8 ppm resonance must arise from PVDF as it is not overlapped with any of the DMF signals, i.e., 7.8, 2.8, or 2.7 ppm. Second, as for the 2.7 ppm resonance, the situation is relatively more complicated because DMF also yields a 2.7 ppm signal (proton “g”). Yet, the 2.7 ppm resonance appears in the “PVDF+PC” sample, which contains no DMF (Fig. 3c), and there is no peak overlap from PC, which evidently reveals that the 2.7 ppm signal is associated with PVDF. As a further support, the 2D 1H-13C CP (cross-polarization) based heteronuclear correlation (HETCOR) spectrum (Fig. 4 a) reveals that the 2.7 ppm signal is correlated with the 40, 37, and 33 ppm carbon resonances, in which the 40 ppm resonance can be readily assigned to the –CH2– group in PVDF and the 37 and 33 ppm resonances can be assigned to the –CH3 groups in DMF, given that –CH2– normally appears on the downfield side (larger ppm values) of –CH3. It shall be noted that the spectral appearance of CPE-1 and CPE-2 (spectra v and vi) are very different, including both the DMF content (indicated by the 7.8 ppm peak) and the PVDF, PC/EC regions (1–5 ppm), which can be reproduced in different batch samples (Fig. S5). Also, PC and PC/EC mixtures exhibit significantly better solvation ability for PVDF compared to pure EC (Fig. 3c), as evidenced by narrower peak widths and higher solvent-to-polymer ratios, consistent with previous reports [38]. Interestingly, the 3.7–3.8 ppm species do not yield any cross-peak in the CP HETCOR spectrum in Fig. 4(a), which is likely attributed to fast molecular dynamics. Normally, CP polarization transfer is based on direct dipolar coupling interaction, i.e., the stronger the coupling, the quicker/more efficient the CP transfer it achieves. However, in systems with molecular motion, a diminished dipolar coupling is commonly observed depending on the rate and mode (e.g., isotropic vs. anisotropic) of the motion, which can lead to insufficient CP transfers and thus the disappearance of cross-peaks in the 2D spectrum [39]. Also, as will be discussed later, a similar phenomenon can be found in the 1H-7Li CP HETCOR spectrum, where only the 2.7 ppm proton yields a correlation to Li+. However, the 2D 1H-7Li HOESY (heteronuclar Overhauser effect spectroscopy) spectrum yields both 1H-7Li correlations of the 2.7 and 3.7–3.8 ppm species. It is well known from the NMR perspective that the cross-relaxation-based HOESY experiment can detect spatial proximity between mobile species, because the polarization transfer is based on non-secular Hamiltonian terms that cannot be completely averaged out by molecular motion [40]. Thus, these results clearly suggest that the 2.7 ppm resonance originates from rigid PVDF chains, while the 3.7–3.8 ppm resonance is associated with highly mobile PVDF segments. Moreover, the chemical shift of the mobile PVDF signal varies across the four PE samples in Fig. 3(a) and exhibits temperature dependence (Fig. 4b), further verifying that the 3.7–3.8 ppm species correspond to PVDF segments residing in a flexible local environment, which is sensitive to additives (solvent, filler, or plasticizer) and thermal motion. With these PVDF mobility assignments, it is worth re-inspecting the structure-property relationship of the pristine PVDF. As shown in the top spectrum in Fig. 3(b), dissolving PVDF in DMF-d7 produces two additional resonances at 3.03 and 2.37 ppm, which can be attributed to the head-tail (H-T) and tail-tail (T-T) configurations of PVDF, respectively (Fig. S6). Clearly, the H-T configuration is present in a much larger quantity. These two configurations might be potentially related to the mobile and rigid PVDF species in the PE samples, as the polarity of H-T is lower than that of T-T, but it certainly requires further and explicit investigations (not in this work). The last assignment remaining is the resonances in CPE-2 (spectrum vi), which is apparently different from any of the spectra in SPE (iii), GPE (iv), or CPE-1 (v). Spectra iii–v all display similar species, aside from variations in peak intensities and minor chemical shift changes (e.g., the 3.7–3.8 ppm PVDF resonance), which can all be unambiguously traced to PVDF, DMF, or PC/EC species. For CPE-2 (vi), however, besides the ∼3.8 and 2.7 ppm resonances that can be readily assigned to mobile and rigid PVDF signals, there are three new resonances emerging at 3.3, 2.2, and 1.9 ppm (marked by diamond symbols, ♦), and the DMF and PC/EC signals are significantly diminished. These species are tentatively attributed to PVDF-DMF or PVDF-PC/EC complexes due to the following observations: (1) all three peaks are present in the GPE spectrum, while only the 2.2 and 1.9 ppm signals appear in the “PVDF+PC/EC” spectrum, implying that the 3.3 ppm signal is DMF-related and that the 2.2 and 1.9 ppm signals are linked to PC/EC; (2) these three peaks persist in both room-temperature dried sample (Fig. S7) and the 60 °C dried sample (spectrum v), whereas the “pure” DMF and PC/EC signals only exist in the room-temperature dried sample, indicating that they are tightly bound species within the material. The exact structures for these species would certainly require more 13C NMR-related experiments in the future, which will not be focused on in this current work, especially given that CPE-1 is the better-performing electrolyte. With the above peak assignments, the 7.8 and 1.3 ppm resonances can be reliably used to monitor the presence of DMF and PC/EC, respectively. A closer inspection of the spectra in Fig. 3(a) clearly shows that significant amounts of residual solvent (7.8 ppm) are present in SPE, GPE, and CPE-1, but not in the DMF-PVDF or CPE-2 samples. This observation highly suggests that the residual solvent may play a critical role in electrolyte performance, especially considering that DMF-Li+ complexes can form and act as effective charge carriers [30]. Moreover, the addition of LiTFSI appears to facilitate DMF incorporation into the system, as evidenced by the pronounced increase of the 7.8 ppm signal and the noticeable line-narrowing effect from spectrum ii to iii. Even more intriguing is the contrast between CPE-1 (spectrum v) and CPE-2 (spectrum vi). Although both are vacuum dried at 60 °C, only CPE-1 retains free solvent and plasticizer, while CPE-2 contains only the tightly bound DMF/PC/EC complex (marked by diamonds). Despite their strong association with the matrix, these species remain highly mobile, as indicated by their narrow linewidths and weak cross-peaks in the 1H-13C 2D CP-HETCOR spectrum (Fig. S8), consistent with high molecular mobility. Importantly, the only variable between CPE-1 and CPE-2 is the sequence of filler and plasticizer addition, yet this results in a substantial disparity in residual solvent content. These findings strongly suggest that the presence or absence of residual solvent is an important factor accounting for the distinct electrochemical behaviors observed on CPE-1 and CPE-2. 3.4 Component interplays in PVDP-CPE To investigate the interactions between solvent/plasticizer and the rigid/mobile polymer chains, 2D 1H-1H nuclear Overhauser effect spectroscopy (NOESY) experiments were performed on the CPE-1 electrolyte, with mixing times of 10, 100 (Fig. S9), and 500 ms (Fig. 5 a). A wealth of cross-peaks among the CPE components are obtained, as detailed in Fig. 5(a). Observed correlations include: (a) the intramolecular correlations within the PC/EC and DMF molecules, (b) the intermolecular correlation between solvent and plasticizer (i.e., DMF, PC/EC), (c) correlations between mobile PVDF and solvent and plasticizer (i.e., mobile PVDF, PC/EC and mobile PVDF, DMF), and (d) correlation between the diamond-denoted species with plasticizer and solvent (i.e., ♦, PC/EC and ♦, DMF). Notably, the mobile PVDF exhibits strong correlations with both DMF and plasticizer molecules, as evidenced by the prominent cross-peaks observed even at the shortest mixing times (10 and 100 ms, Fig. S9). Its abundant correlations indicate that at least the mobile PVDF segments are strongly interacting with the solvent and plasticizer, indicating an environment with suppressed crystallization or lamellar formation, which is essential for high Li+ conductivity. Also, DMF is universally correlated with nearly all species, suggesting that it plays a critical role in the formation of the highly amorphous (or mobile) environment for the CPE material. Then, a key unresolved question is whether the rigid PVDF segments (resonating at 2.7 ppm) also contribute to the Li+ conduction pathways. Investigating their correlation with DMF or plasticizer could provide valuable insights; however, these correlations are currently obscured due to signal overlap with the DMF peak at 2.7 ppm, which itself shows correlations with nearly all species. This limitation could potentially be addressed in future studies by employing deuterated DMF. Interestingly, the three resonances at 3.3, 2.2, and 1.9 ppm, prominent in CPE-2 but nearly absent in CPE-1 (see 1D spectra v and vi, Fig. 3a), show strong correlation signals in the NOESY spectra. These findings suggest that these species play a significant role in the structural organization of the CPE. However, their exact molecular identities and contributions to Li+ conductivity remain elusive, warranting further investigation, particularly in the context of CPE-2. The role of the DMF solvent is of essential importance, given its universal correlations within the system. In CPE-1, the residual DMF appears thermally stable. Increasing the vacuum drying temperature from 60 to 120 °C does not affect the intensity of the DMF peak at 7.8 ppm (Fig. 5b). In contrast, PC/EC species, represented by peaks at 4–5 and 1.3 ppm, as denoted in the figure, are completely removed under these conditions. For CPE-2, however, raising the vacuum drying temperature from 60 to 100 °C causes negligible spectral change, consistent with the prior removal of most solvents and plasticizers (Fig. 5c). The persistence of the three peaks marked with diamonds further supports their assignment as tightly bound DMF-PVDF and PC/EC-PVDF complexes. Interestingly, a slight shift of the mobile PVDF peak near 4 ppm is observed upon vacuum drying at higher temperatures, from ca. 4.1 to 3.7 ppm, as indicated in the figure. One should also note that the 60 °C vacuum-dried sample (spectrum vi, Fig. 3a) yields a slightly different peak position (3.9 ppm), suggesting that the local environment of the mobile PVDF is sensitive to sample preparation conditions, a well-known phenomenon in battery materials [41,42]. Notably, both CPEs exhibit reduced electrochemical performance when dried at above 60 °C (Fig. S10), possibly due to disruptions in the solvent-plasticizer system. This result highlights that preparation temperatures should not exceed 60 °C to preserve optimal electrolyte properties. These observations offer a tentative explanation for the pronounced differences between CPE-1 and CPE-2 displayed in Fig. 1(f). The performance enhancement in CPE-1 by SBA-15 filler is likely not due to intrinsic Li+ conduction, but rather to its influence on the PVDF morphology and the residual solvent content. In particular, the early addition of the SBA-15 filler in CPE-2, prior to LiTFSI and plasticizer, may promote PVDF nucleation [43–45], hindering uniform integration of solvent and plasticizer into the polymer matrix. As a result, most mobile solvent and plasticizer molecules are removed during the casting and drying processes, leaving behind only the tightly bound species. 3.5 Factors determining the Li+ mobility in CPE To investigate the Li+ mobility-structure interactions within the CPE systems, which is fundamental to understanding the Li+ transport mechanism, 2D 1H-7Li correlation NMR experiments were performed using both HOESY and CP-based polarization transfers (Fig. 6 ). A series of mixing times were tested for the HOESY experiment, with 1 ms selected based on optimal correlation efficiency (Fig. S11). Recall that the HOESY spectrum detects spatial correlations regardless of molecular motions, and CP HETCOR only detects species with relatively rigid environments. It should also be noted that all proton peaks in the 2D HOESY and CP HETCOR spectra exhibit significantly broader line widths than those in the corresponding 1D spectrum, with CP spectra showing the broadest peaks. This is expected that, as a broader line in MAS NMR generally reflects restricted molecular motions, CP transfer is more sensitive to such motion than HOESY, which relies on cross-relaxation. For CPE-1, Li+ shows clear correlations with both rigid and mobile PVDF segments, as well as with solvent (DMF) and plasticizer (PC) components. However, in the CP HETCOR spectrum, the Li+/mobile PVDF correlation is significantly diminished despite its high proton signal intensity in the 1D spectrum (which is quantitative), indicating a highly dynamic environment of these species. It is worth noting that the mobile PVDF yields an even stronger correlation than the rigid PVDF to Li+, considering the much smaller peak intensity in the 1D spectrum of the former. For CPE-2, the HOESY spectrum reveals a universal Li+ correlation with all proton species, suggesting that each contributes to Li+ transport, however, to varying extents due to the differing cross-peak intensities, and importantly, mobile PVDF also yields the most intense cross-peak. With all the above information evaluated, it can be concluded that rigid and mobile PVDF together provide the primary role in constructing Li+ pathways, the mobile fraction playing a more dominant role. The 1H-7Li correlation also provides important information on the role of the solvent. A strong and narrow (in the proton dimension) DMF-Li+ correlation is observed in the HOESY spectrum for CPE-1 (Fig. 6a), and such a correlation is also observed in HOESY for CPE-2 (Fig. 6b) despite the low DMF content; this phenomenon indicates a close spatial relationship between Li+ and residual DMF, which strongly suggest the formation of DMF-Li+ complex [46]. Additionally, the narrow proton linewidth of the cross-peak suggests the high mobility of these species. Hence, it is rational to conclude that the DMF-Li+ complex (whole as a charge carrier) provides additional contributions to the Li+ migration besides the polymer matrices (mobile and rigid moieties). Based on the discussions above, a schematic of the proposed Li+ transport pathways for the best-performing CPE-1 system is presented in Fig. 7 . The PVDF matrix plays a central role in facilitating Li+ mobility and constructing ion transport pathways. Both rigid and mobile PVDF chains are involved in this process, while the mobile PVDF fractions show a stronger contribution to Li+ transport. Additionally, the solvent plays an assistant role in facilitating the Li+ transport by forming DMF-Li+ complexes that act as mobile charge carriers, of which the mechanism has been previously proposed by Chen et al. [30]. This model aligns with the superior performance of CPE-1 over CPE-2, likely due to its higher DMF content. Also, the DMF-Li+ complexes may not only contribute to charge carriers but also assist in forming continuous (or more options for) conduction pathways, given their greater mobility compared to the polymer matrix. Because of the small quantities, it is most likely that the zeolite filler and plasticizer (PC/EC) enhance the CPE performance primarily by influencing the morphology of the PVDF network, but not by directly creating Li+ pathways. Yet, several open questions remain: How do the –CF2– groups in PVDF contribute to Li+ transport? What are the precise molecular structures of the DMF-PVDF and plasticizer-PVDF complexes in CPE-2, and how do they facilitate Li+ transport? How are these interactions affected by just changing the order of filler-plasticizer addition? And what is the quantitative relationship between solvent content and ionic conductivity? 4 Conclusions In this study, a PVDF-based composite electrolyte material was developed, exhibiting remarkable room-temperature Li+ conductivity (>1 mS cm−1) and mobility (0.95 × 10−11 m2 s−1), along with excellent electrochemical performances, including a high reversible discharge capacity of 154 mAh g−1 at 0.1 C with a LiFePO4 cathode, a 90 % capacity retention after 160 cycles at 0.2 C, a wide stability window (4.8 V vs. Li/Li+), and a large transference number (t Li+ = 0.42). Systematic investigations of the SPE, GPE, and CPE materials using high-field NMR and 2D correlation NMR spectroscopy (1H-1H NOESY, 1H-13C, and 1H-7Li HOESY/CP-HETCOR) revealed two key polymer regions influencing Li+ mobility: the rigid and mobile PVDF segments. Among these, the mobile PVDF segments were found to play a more dominant role in facilitating Li+ mobility/conductivity. Clear evidence also revealed that stable Li+-solvent (DMF) complexes can form and act as charge carriers in the CPE materials. Furthermore, it was demonstrated that adding the filler prior to the plasticizer component during the CPE fabrication causes nucleation of the PVDF chain, thus preventing the formation of DMF-Li+ complexes, which accounts for the reduced ion conductivity and degraded performance. coredata.dc:description: Composite polymer electrolytes (CPEs) are considered as promising electrolytes for next-generation lithium batteries due to their superior advantages in safety, mechanical stability/flexibility, cathode compatibility, etc. However, achieving high Li+ conductivity remains a major challenge, particularly at low temperatures. A key obstacle lies in the limited understanding of the complex interplay among amorphous components, including fillers, plasticizers, and residual solvents, which significantly hampers the rational design of high-performing CPEs. In this contribution, a polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF)-based composite electrolyte has been developed, exhibiting high room-temperature ionic conductivity/mobility (>1 mS cm−1/0.95 × 10−11 m2 s−1), along with excellent electrochemical performances, including a wide stability window (4.8 V vs. Li/Li+), superior charge/discharge capacity, and reversibility. By performing advanced solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (ssNMR) techniques, in combination with systematic investigations into solid polymer electrolytes (SPEs), gel polymer electrolytes (GPEs), and CPEs, we establish an efficient NMR-based strategy for deconvoluting the structural and dynamic features of complex electrolyte systems. Notably, the simple 1H magic-angle spinning (MAS) NMR spectroscopy enables the identification and monitoring of nearly all components in the composite matrix. Motion-sensitive 1H-13C and 1H-7Li correlation experiments further reveal that the rigidity of PVDF polymer chain segments and the presence of residual solvents are two critical factors governing Li+ mobility. Moreover, we demonstrate that the order of the filler and plasticizer addition during the CPE fabrication significantly influences the performance of the electrolyte by regulating the retention of residual solvents. This work not only provides molecular-level insights into the structure-ion mobility relationships in the PVDF-based CPEs but also establishes a general NMR-based characterization approach for investigating other complex composite electrolyte materials.
